body_html:
@Stonesjtu #4226 is just about build support. There're lots of tests that can't pass in the 2.7 build. But at that time, a simple MNIST example ran smoothly. I think that it is not easy to fix these issues.
Take os.ppid as an example, there are two possible ways to fix this.

  1. Use getppid from psutils. But it requires external dependencies.
  2. Implement os.ppid using standard libs. Example. But it introduces os specific code, which is not so good.

There're many similar issues like this, like long long support in struct and etc. I wonder whether there are some better solutions to this situation. But the easiest one is to drop support.

Take os.ppid as an example, there are two possible ways to fix this.

Use getppid from psutils. But it requires external dependencies.
Implement os.ppid using standard libs. Example. But it introduces os specific code, which is not so good.

There're many similar issues like this, like long long support in struct and etc. I wonder whether there are some better solutions to this situation. But the easiest one is to drop support.
body:
@Stonesjtu #4226 is just about build support. There're lots of tests that can't pass in the 2.7 build. But at that time, a simple MNIST example ran smoothly. I think that it is not easy to fix these issues. 
Take `os.ppid` as an example, there are two possible ways to fix this.
1. Use `getppid` from psutils. But it requires external dependencies.
2. Implement `os.ppid` using standard libs. [Example](http://d.hatena.ne.jp/chrono-meter/20090325/p1). But it introduces os specific code, which is not so good.

There're many similar issues like this, like `long long` support in `struct` and etc. I wonder whether there are some better solutions to this situation. But the easiest one is to drop support.
